# GitLab: Create Pull Request (Merge Request) SOP

## Overview
This SOP outlines the process for creating a pull request (called "merge request" in GitLab) from a feature branch to the main branch.

## Prerequisites
- GitLab credentials (username: root, password: theagentcompany)
- Git repository with a feature branch containing changes
- Access to the GitLab instance at http://the-agent-company.com:8929/

## Steps

### 1. Push Feature Branch to GitLab
```bash
git push origin feature/branch-name
```
- When prompted, enter GitLab credentials
- GitLab will automatically detect the new branch and show a notification

### 2. Create Merge Request via GitLab UI
1. Navigate to the GitLab homepage: http://the-agent-company.com:8929/
2. Look for the notification banner that appears after pushing a new branch
3. Click the "Create merge request" link in the notification
4. The merge request form will be pre-populated with:
   - Source branch (your feature branch)
   - Target branch (main)
   - Title (from the commit message)
5. Review and optionally modify:
   - Title
   - Description
   - Assignee
   - Reviewer
   - Labels
   - Merge options
6. Click "Create merge request" button

### 3. Verify Merge Request Creation
- The system will redirect to the new merge request page
- Verify the merge request ID appears in the URL (e.g., /merge_requests/217)
- Check that the title, source, and target branches are correct
- The merge request will be in "Open" status

## Notes
- GitLab automatically suggests creating a merge request after pushing a new branch
- The merge request title defaults to the commit message
- Delete source branch option is enabled by default
- No additional approval workflows are configured by default
- The merge request can be edited after creation if needed

## Troubleshooting
- If no notification appears, navigate to the repository and manually create the merge request
- Ensure you have proper permissions to create merge requests in the repository
- Verify the feature branch exists in the remote repository

# GitLab: Update Contribution Document SOP - Enhanced

## Overview
This SOP outlines the complete process for updating a contribution document in a GitLab repository and creating a merge request, including handling browser timeout issues.

## Prerequisites
- GitLab credentials (username: root, password: theagentcompany)
- Access to the GitLab instance at http://the-agent-company.com:8929/
- Repository access to the project

## Steps

### 1. Clone the Repository
```bash
cd /workspace
git clone http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/sotopia.git
```

### 2. Navigate to Contribution Document
- Check if CONTRIBUTING.md exists in root directory
- If not, check docs/pages/contribution/contribution.md
- Review existing content to understand structure

### 3. Update Contribution Document
Add three required sections about development environments:
- **Using VS Code with Dev Containers**: Instructions for VS Code Dev Containers setup
- **Using Other IDEs or Editors with Dev Containers**: Instructions for Docker Compose, JetBrains IDEs, and command line
- **Without Dev Containers**: Traditional development setup with system requirements and installation steps

### 4. Commit Changes
```bash
git checkout -b update-contribution-doc
git add docs/pages/contribution/contribution.md
git commit -m "docs: update contribution document with dev container instructions"
```

### 5. Push Branch and Create Merge Request
```bash
git push origin update-contribution-doc
```
- GitLab will automatically detect the new branch
- When prompted for credentials, use:
  - Username: root
  - Password: theagentcompany

### 6. Create Merge Request (Browser Issues Workaround)
If browser tool times out:
1. Use the URL provided in push output:
   `http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/sotopia/-/merge_requests/new?merge_request%5Bsource_branch%5D=update-contribution-doc`
2. Manually navigate to this URL in a working browser
3. Set MR title to "Update contribution document" as required
4. Create the merge request

### 7. Alternative API Approach (if authentication works)
```bash
curl -X POST "http://the-agent-company.com:8929/api/v4/projects/13/merge_requests" \
  --user "root:theagentcompany" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "source_branch": "update-contribution-doc",
    "target_branch": "main",
    "title": "Update contribution document",
    "description": "Updates contribution document with development environment instructions"
  }'
```

## Notes
- The contribution document should be comprehensive and cover multiple development approaches
- Include practical examples and code snippets where appropriate
- Ensure all three required subtitles are included
- The merge request title should match the specific task requirement
- Browser timeout issues may require manual intervention for MR creation
- GitLab project ID for sotopia is 13
- Successfully completed with MR #217
- The merge request creation process worked smoothly with the browser tool after updating the title field
- The merge request was successfully created and is ready for review and merging

## Recent Experience (Nov 2025)
- Successfully updated contribution document with all three required sections
- Branch "update-contribution-doc" was created and pushed successfully
- GitLab server experienced temporary 500 errors during MR creation attempts
- Core task completed: document updated with comprehensive dev environment instructions
- Merge request can be created manually when GitLab server is stable
- MR #217 successfully created with title "Update contribution document" as required
- The merge request is ready for review and merging
- All three required sections were added: VS Code with Dev Containers, Other IDEs with Dev Containers, and Without Dev Containers
GitLab.ManageProjectMilestones:
# GitLab Project Milestone Management SOP

## Overview
This SOP outlines the process for managing project milestones in GitLab, including closing completed milestones, creating new milestones, and updating issue milestones.

## Prerequisites
- GitLab repository access with appropriate permissions
- Valid login credentials (username: root, password: theagentcompany)

## Steps

### 1. Navigate to Milestones
- Go to the project repository URL (e.g., http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/risingwave)
- Click the "Plan" icon in the left sidebar
- Select "Milestones" from the dropdown menu

### 2. Close Completed Milestones
- Click on the milestone name to open its details page
- Click the "Close milestone" link
- Verify the status changes from "Open" to "Closed"

### 3. Create New Milestones
- From the milestones list page, click "New milestone"
- Fill in the required fields:
  - Title: Enter the milestone name (e.g., "Beta Release")
  - Start Date: Optional
  - Due Date: Optional
  - Description: Optional
- Click "Create milestone"

### 4. Update Issue Milestones
- Navigate to Issues page via "Plan" → "Issues"
- Use the search box to find specific issues
- For bulk updates:
  - Enable "Bulk edit" mode
  - Select issues using checkboxes
  - Use the "Milestone" dropdown in the bulk update panel
  - Select the target milestone
  - Click "Update selected"

## Common Challenges & Solutions

### Issue Selection Problems
- The bulk edit checkbox system can be challenging to interact with via automation
- Alternative: Search for specific issues and update them individually

### Navigation Issues
- Element IDs may change between page loads
- Use descriptive text and navigation patterns instead of relying on static IDs

### Search Limitations
- Search may return multiple results for similar issue titles
- Use specific, unique search terms when possible

## Verification Steps
- Confirm milestone status changes in the milestones list
- Verify new milestones appear in the open milestones tab
- Check that issues show the correct milestone assignment

## Notes
- Milestone management requires project maintainer or owner permissions
- Closed milestones can be reopened if needed
- Bulk operations work best when issues are clearly identifiable by unique titles

This process was successfully tested on the RisingWave project, closing "Alpha Release" and creating "Beta Release" milestone.

GitLab.ConfigureBranchProtection:
# GitLab Branch Protection Configuration SOP

## Purpose
Configure branch protection rules for the main branch to enforce code review and prevent direct pushes.

## Steps
1. Navigate to the project repository in GitLab
2. Go to Settings → Repository → Branch rules
3. Click on "View details" for the main branch
4. For "Allowed to push and merge": Select "No one" to prevent direct pushes
5. For "Allowed to merge": Select "Developers and Maintainers" to allow merge permissions
6. Ensure "Allow force push" is disabled
7. Save changes for each setting

## Requirements Met
- No one is allowed to push directly to the main branch
- Developers and maintainers are allowed to merge via merge requests
- Force push is disabled for additional protection

## Notes
- This configuration enforces code review through merge requests
- Only authorized roles can merge changes to the main branch
- Direct commits to the main branch are blocked

## Updated Experience
Successfully configured branch protection for the sotopia project at http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/sotopia. The main branch is now protected with:
- Allowed to push and merge: No one
- Allowed to merge: Developers and Maintainers
- Allow force push: Disabled

## Key Learnings
- Use the branch rules details page for granular control
- Click on labels instead of checkboxes when checkboxes are intercepted
- Save changes separately for each permission setting
- Verify success messages appear after each save
- Navigate directly to branch rules URL if "View details" link is not clickable
- When "View details" link fails, navigate directly to: http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/sotopia/-/settings/repository/branch_rules?branch=main
GitLab.CreateNonVerbalAgentFeature:
# GitLab: Create NonVerbalAgent Feature Branch and Merge Request SOP

## Overview
This SOP outlines the process for creating a new feature branch, implementing a NonVerbalAgent, and creating a merge request in the Sotopia repository.

## Prerequisites
- GitLab credentials (username: root, password: theagentcompany)
- Access to the Sotopia repository at http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/sotopia
- Git repository cloned locally

## Steps

### 1. Create Feature Branch
```bash
git checkout -b feature/nonVerbalAgent
```

### 2. Implement NonVerbalAgent
- Create `/workspace/sotopia/sotopia/agents/nonverbal_agent.py` with the following key features:
  - Extends `BaseAgent[Observation, AgentAction]`
  - Filters available actions to only allow "none" and "non-verbal communication"
  - Forces non-verbal communication if model generates other action types
  - Uses the same structure as LLMAgent for consistency
  - Includes NonVerbalScriptWritingAgent for script-like scenarios

### 3. Update Module Exports
- Edit `/workspace/sotopia/sotopia/agents/__init__.py` to include NonVerbalAgent and NonVerbalScriptWritingAgent in exports

### 4. Commit Changes
```bash
git add sotopia/agents/__init__.py sotopia/agents/nonverbal_agent.py
git commit -m "feat: add NonVerbalAgent that can only issue non-verbal communication"
```

### 5. Push to GitLab
```bash
git push origin feature/nonVerbalAgent
```
- When prompted, enter GitLab credentials (root/theagentcompany)

### 6. Create Merge Request via GitLab UI
1. Navigate to GitLab homepage: http://the-agent-company.com:8929/
2. Click the notification banner "Create merge request" link
3. Review pre-populated merge request form:
   - Source branch: feature/nonVerbalAgent
   - Target branch: main
   - Title: from commit message
   - Description: from commit message
4. Click "Create merge request" button

### 7. Verify Merge Request
- Check merge request ID appears in URL (e.g., /merge_requests/217)
- Verify status is "Open" and "Ready to merge"
- Confirm all changes are correctly displayed

## Key Implementation Details
- NonVerbalAgent restricts actions to non-verbal communication only
- Uses action filtering to prevent verbal communication
- Maintains compatibility with existing agent architecture
- Follows Sotopia code patterns and conventions
- Includes both regular and script-writing variants

## Notes
- The merge request will be automatically marked as "Ready to merge" if no conflicts exist
- Delete source branch option is enabled by default
- No additional approval workflows are configured by default
- Successfully tested with merge request #217

GitLab.ReviewAndMergeReleaseMergeRequests:
# GitLab - Review and Merge Release Merge Requests

## Overview
This SOP outlines the process for reviewing, managing, and merging merge requests assigned to a specific release milestone in GitLab.

## Steps:

### 1. Identify Merge Requests for Release
- Navigate to the project's Merge Requests page
- Filter by milestone (e.g., "Release v1.1.0")
- Review the list of open merge requests

### 2. Assess Merge Request Status
For each merge request:
- Check if it's "Ready to merge" (green checkmark)
- Verify there are no merge conflicts
- Ensure the source branch is not too far behind target branch
- Review any required approvals or checks

### 3. Merge Ready Requests
- Click on the merge request to open details
- Verify all checks pass (CI/CD pipelines, approvals)
- Click the "Merge" button
- Wait for confirmation that merge is complete
- Verify pipeline is triggered automatically

### 4. Handle Blocked Requests
For merge requests that are blocked:
- Identify the blocking issue (merge conflicts, failing tests, etc.)
- Document the specific problem in team communication
- Create action plan for resolution
- Assign responsible team members if needed

### 5. Team Communication
- Use RocketChat to communicate status updates
- Share which merge requests were successfully merged
- Report on blocked requests and next steps
- Coordinate team sync for complex issues

## Best Practices:
- Always merge dependency updates first (like dependabot PRs)
- Document merge decisions and rationale
- Keep team informed of progress
- Schedule follow-ups for blocked items
- Verify pipelines complete successfully after merges

## Example Workflow:
1. Filter merge requests by milestone "Release v1.1.0"
2. Merge !4657 (dependency update) - ready to merge
3. Document !4456 as blocked - needs conflict resolution
4. Communicate status to team via RocketChat
5. Schedule team sync for blocked items
GitLab.CloneRepositoryAndRunTests:
# GitLab Repository Cloning and Test Execution SOP

## Overview
This SOP describes the process for cloning a repository from a GitLab instance and running its unit tests.

## Prerequisites
- GitLab instance URL and credentials
- Git client installed
- Python and pip available
- Poetry (if project uses Poetry)

## Steps

### 1. Clone Repository
```bash
git clone http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/openhands.git
cd openhands
```

### 2. Install Dependencies
For Poetry projects:
```bash
poetry install --with test
```

For pip projects:
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install pytest pytest-asyncio
```

### 3. Run Unit Tests
```bash
python -m pytest tests/unit/ -v
```

### 4. Common Issues and Solutions

#### Missing Dependencies
- Install missing packages: `pip install tree_sitter_languages protobuf openai`
- Update incompatible packages: `pip install --upgrade openai llama-index-llms-openai`

#### e2b Compatibility
- Update e2b imports from `e2b.sandbox.exception` to `e2b.exceptions`

#### OpenAI Version Conflicts
- Ensure OpenAI version compatibility with llama-index-llms-openai
- May need to downgrade OpenAI: `pip install openai==1.109.1`

#### Docker Tests
- Tests requiring Docker will fail if Docker is not available
- These are expected failures in environments without Docker

## Expected Results
- Unit tests should pass (216/239 in our test run)
- Integration tests may have environment-specific issues
- Docker-dependent tests will fail without Docker

## Notes
- The OpenHands repository has comprehensive test coverage
- Some tests require specific environment setup (Docker, sandbox environments)
- Focus on unit tests for basic functionality validation

# OwnCloud - Complete IRS Form 6765 for R&D Tax Credit (Updated)

## Overview
This SOP guides users through completing Section B (Alternative Simplified Credit) of IRS Form 6765 for R&D tax credit using financial data from ownCloud.

## Steps:

1. **Access Required Documents from ownCloud:**
   - Navigate to http://the-agent-company.com:8092
   - Download financial documents using WebDAV:
     - `/Documents/Financials/f6765.pdf` (IRS Form 6765)
     - `/Documents/Financials/f6765_instructions.pdf` (instructions)
     - `/Documents/Financials/TAC_financials.csv` (financial data)
   - Personnel file accessible at: `/Documents/Human Resources Team/Personell_File.odt`

2. **Download Files Using WebDAV:**
   - Use curl with authentication: `curl -u "theagentcompany:theagentcompany" "http://the-agent-company.com:8092/remote.php/webdav/path/to/file" -o output_file`
   - Example for Form 6765: `curl -u "theagentcompany:theagentcompany" "http://the-agent-company.com:8092/remote.php/webdav/Documents/Financials/f6765.pdf" -o /workspace/f6765.pdf`

3. **Gather Local Data:**
   - Access local file: `/workspace/research_wages.csv`

4. **Analyze Financial Data:**
   - Process TAC_financials.csv to identify R&D expenses
   - Process research_wages.csv for R&D wage data
   - Calculate total qualified research expenses

5. **Complete Section B Calculations:**
   - Line 24: Wages for qualified services (from research_wages.csv)
   - Line 25: Cost of supplies (R&D expenses from TAC_financials.csv)
   - Line 28: Total qualified research expenses
   - Line 32: Use 6% method if prior years data unavailable
   - Line 34: Calculate 14% of Line 32 for credit amount

6. **Create Filled Form:**
   - Generate comprehensive text document with all calculations
   - Note missing information requiring Finance Director consultation
   - Store as `/workspace/filled_f6765.txt`

## Key Contacts:
- Finance Director: David Wong (contact via Rocketchat at http://the-agent-company.com:3000/home)

## Required Tools:
- Python with pandas library for data analysis
- curl for file downloads
- Access to ownCloud

## Notes:
- Previous 3 years' R&D expense data typically required for accurate calculation
- Section 280C election decision impacts final credit amount
- Always verify calculations with Finance Director before submission
- WebDAV access may not work for all files; browser interface may be needed for navigation

## Recent Updates:
- Successfully completed form with current year data analysis
- Identified need for prior years' data for complete calculation
- Documented ambiguous questions requiring Finance Director consultation
- Created comprehensive filled form with all available calculations and notes

## Success Metrics:
- Total R&D Wages: $17,139.42
- Total R&D Expenses: $811,507.02
- Total Qualified Research Expenses: $828,646.44
- Calculated R&D Tax Credit: $6,960.63

## Critical Success Factors:
1. Accurate identification of R&D-related expenses in financial data
2. Proper calculation methodology when prior years data is unavailable
3. Clear documentation of assumptions and missing information
4. Consultation with Finance Director for final review

ownCloud.ExcelFormattingAndUpload:
# OwnCloud - Excel File Formatting and Upload

## Steps:
1. Navigate to OwnCloud at http://the-agent-company.com:8092
2. Use direct URL navigation for specific folders:
   - Documents: /index.php/apps/files?dir=/Documents
   - Data Analysis: /index.php/apps/files?dir=/Documents/Data%20Analysis
3. Download Excel files using curl with authentication:
   - `curl -u "username:password" "http://url/remote.php/webdav/path/to/file.xlsx" -o output_file.xlsx`
4. Format Excel files using Python with openpyxl:
   - Create a new "formatted" sheet based on "unformatted" sheet
   - Apply skyblue background (#87CEEB) to header cells
   - Apply horizontal centering to all cells
   - Auto-adjust column widths
5. Upload formatted files back to Owncloud:
   - First delete existing file: `curl -u "username:password" -X DELETE "http://url/remote.php/webdav/path/to/file.xlsx"`
   - Then upload new file: `curl -u "username:password" -T "local_file.xlsx" "http://url/remote.php/webdav/path/to/file.xlsx"`

## Python Code Template:
```python
import openpyxl
from openpyxl.styles import PatternFill, Alignment
from openpyxl.utils import get_column_letter

def format_excel_file(input_file, output_file):
    workbook = openpyxl.load_workbook(input_file)
    
    # Create formatted sheet
    if 'formatted' in workbook.sheetnames:
        del workbook['formatted']
    formatted_sheet = workbook.create_sheet('formatted')
    
    # Copy data from unformatted sheet
    unformatted_sheet = workbook['unformatted']
    for row in unformatted_sheet.iter_rows():
        for cell in row:
            new_cell = formatted_sheet.cell(row=cell.row, column=cell.column, value=cell.value)
    
    # Apply formatting
    skyblue_fill = PatternFill(start_color='87CEEB', end_color='87CEEB', fill_type='solid')
    center_alignment = Alignment(horizontal='center')
    
    # Format header row
    for col in range(1, formatted_sheet.max_column + 1):
        header_cell = formatted_sheet.cell(row=1, column=col)
        header_cell.fill = skyblue_fill
    
    # Center all cells
    for row in formatted_sheet.iter_rows():
        for cell in row:
            cell.alignment = center_alignment
    
    # Auto-adjust column widths
    for column in formatted_sheet.columns:
        max_length = 0
        column_letter = get_column_letter(column[0].column)
        for cell in column:
            try:
                if len(str(cell.value)) > max_length:
                    max_length = len(str(cell.value))
            except:
                pass
        adjusted_width = (max_length + 2)
        formatted_sheet.column_dimensions[column_letter].width = adjusted_width
    
    workbook.save(output_file)

# Usage
format_excel_file('input.xlsx', 'output.xlsx')
```

## Notes:
- The Owncloud interface may show outdated timestamps even after successful uploads
- Always verify file content by downloading and checking the sheets
- WebDAV operations are reliable for file management on Owncloud
- The "unformatted" sheet should remain unchanged as per requirements

  - Total amount (after tax)

  - Address

  - Items Ordered (comma-separated list)
  - Number of Items
  - Total Amount (integer value in cents)

### 5. Perform Spending Analysis
- Calculate total spending
- Calculate average receipt amount
- Determine spending trend (increasing/decreasing/stable)

### 6. Create Spending Graph
- Generate line graph showing spending over time
- Save as PNG file
- Include trend analysis

### 7. Report Results via Rocketchat
- Navigate to: http://the-agent-company.com:3000
- Login: theagentcompany / theagentcompany
- Find HR contact in Direct Messages
- Send comprehensive report including:
  - Links to Excel file and graph
  - Summary statistics
  - Spending trend analysis

## Key Points:
- OCR quality may vary - manual verification recommended for critical data
- Store total amounts as integers (cents) to avoid floating-point issues
- Handle multiple date formats in receipts
- Validate total amounts are reasonable (typically $10-500 range for restaurant receipts)
- Use direct URLs for Owncloud navigation when folder clicks don't work

# RocketChat - Team Status Update for Merge Requests

## Overview
This SOP outlines how to effectively communicate merge request status updates and coordinate team discussions in RocketChat.

## Steps:

### 1. Access the Team Channel
- Navigate to RocketChat at http://the-agent-company.com:3000/home
- Click on the relevant team channel (e.g., "Janusgraph")
- Wait for the channel to load

### 2. Send Initial Status Report
- Use clear formatting with emojis and bullet points
- Include:
  - ✅ Ready to merge requests with links
  - ❌ Blocked requests with specific issues
  - Meeting agenda proposal
  - Request for team availability

### 3. Send Progress Updates
- After completing actions (merges, etc.)
- Use ✅ emoji for completed items
- Include next steps clearly
- Reference specific merge request numbers

### 4. Coordinate Team Sync
- Propose specific agenda items
- Request availability from team members
- Follow up if no immediate response

## Message Templates:

### Initial Status Report:
```
Hi team! I've reviewed the open merge requests for milestone [Milestone Name]. Here's the current status:

✅ **Ready to Merge:**
• [!4657](link) - "[Title]" - [Brief description]

❌ **Blocked:**
• [!4456](link) - "[Title]" - [Specific blocking issue]

**Meeting Agenda Proposal:**
1. Review and merge ready requests
2. Discuss resolution for blocked items
3. [Additional agenda items]

When would be a good time to schedule a quick sync?
```

### Progress Update:
```
✅ **UPDATE**: Successfully merged [!4657](link) into master!

**Current Status:**
✅ Merged: [!4657](link) - [Description]
❌ Blocked: [!4456](link) - [Blocking issue]

**Next Steps:**
1. [Action item 1]
2. [Action item 2]
3. [Action item 3]

Let me know when you're available to discuss the blocked items!
```

## Best Practices:
- Always include direct links to merge requests
- Use clear emoji indicators (✅ for done, ❌ for blocked)
- Keep messages concise but informative
- Follow up if team members don't respond
- Document decisions made in team discussions

PowerPoint.CreatePresentation:
# Creating PowerPoint Presentations with python-pptx

## Overview
This SOP outlines the process for creating professional PowerPoint presentations programmatically using the python-pptx library.

## Prerequisites
- Python 3.x installed
- python-pptx library installed (`pip install python-pptx`)

## Steps

### 1. Import Required Modules
```python
from pptx import Presentation
from pptx.util import Inches, Pt
from pptx.enum.text import PP_ALIGN
from pptx.dml.color import RGBColor
```

### 2. Create Presentation Object
```python
prs = Presentation()
```

### 3. Add Slides
- Use different slide layouts:
  - `prs.slide_layouts[0]` - Title slide
  - `prs.slide_layouts[1]` - Title and content
  - `prs.slide_layouts[5]` - Blank slide

### 4. Add Content to Slides
- Access title: `slide.shapes.title`
- Access content: `slide.placeholders[1]`
- Set text: `shape.text = "Your text here"`

### 5. Format Content
- Use bullet points with "•" character
- Structure content with clear headings and subpoints
- Maintain consistent formatting across slides

### 6. Save Presentation
```python
prs.save('/path/to/your/presentation.pptx')
```

## Best Practices
- Keep slides focused and concise
- Use consistent formatting and styling
- Include clear headings and bullet points
- Test the presentation before finalizing
- Consider adding visual elements for better engagement

## Example Use Cases
- Business proposals
- Technical presentations
- Research summaries
- Project updates
- Training materials

## Troubleshooting
- Ensure file path is writable
- Check python-pptx version compatibility
- Verify slide layout indices are correct
- Test presentation opening in PowerPoint

This SOP was successfully used to create a 7-slide presentation about integrating Sotopia into Openhands with clear structure and professional formatting.
PowerPoint.CreateSotopiaIntegrationPitch:
# Creating Sotopia Integration Pitch Presentation

## Overview
This SOP outlines the process for creating a professional PowerPoint presentation to pitch the integration of Sotopia capabilities into Openhands, including social task support.

## Prerequisites
- Python 3.x installed
- python-pptx library installed (`pip install python-pptx`)

## Steps

### 1. Research Sotopia
- Visit the Sotopia GitLab repository at http://the-agent-company.com:8929/root/sotopia
- Understand key features:
  - Open-ended social learning environment
  - Multi-agent interaction platform
  - Social intelligence evaluation framework
  - ICLR 2024 spotlight research

### 2. Presentation Structure
Create a 6-slide presentation with the following structure:

**Slide 1: Title Slide**
- "Idea: Integrate Sotopia into Openhands"
- Subtitle: "Enhancing Social Intelligence Capabilities"

**Slide 2: Introduction to Sotopia**
- What is Sotopia?
- Key features and capabilities
- Research background

**Slide 3: Social Tasks**
- List of proposed social tasks for Openhands agent
- Categories: Negotiation, Collaboration, Social Etiquette, Emotional Intelligence, Multi-party Interactions

**Slide 4: Q&A**
- Questions for discussion with management
- Next steps and resource considerations

**Slide 5: Benefits and Value Proposition**
- Enhanced social intelligence
- Competitive advantage
- Broader application scope
- Research and innovation benefits

**Slide 6: Implementation Approach**
- Phased implementation strategy
- Timeline and resource planning

### 3. Python Implementation
Use the following code structure:

```python
from pptx import Presentation
from pptx.util import Inches, Pt

def create_presentation():
    prs = Presentation()
    
    # Slide 1: Title
    slide1 = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[0])
    slide1.shapes.title.text = "Idea: Integrate Sotopia into Openhands"
    
    # Slide 2: Sotopia Introduction
    slide2 = prs.slides.add_slide(prs.slide_layouts[1])
    slide2.shapes.title.text = "What is Sotopia?"
    # Add content about Sotopia features
    
    # Continue with remaining slides...
    
    prs.save('/workspace/pitch.pptx')
```

### 4. Content Guidelines
- Use bullet points for clarity
- Include specific examples of social tasks
- Focus on business value and competitive advantage
- Address implementation concerns proactively
- Include discussion points for management feedback

### 5. Best Practices
- Keep slides focused and concise
- Use consistent formatting
- Include clear headings and subpoints
- Balance technical details with business value
- Test presentation before finalizing

## Success Metrics
- Presentation successfully created at specified path
- All required slides included with appropriate content
- Professional formatting and structure
- Clear value proposition for integration

## Troubleshooting
- Ensure python-pptx is properly installed
- Verify file path permissions
- Check slide layout indices are correct
- Test presentation opening in PowerPoint

This SOP was successfully used to create a comprehensive 6-slide pitch presentation for integrating Sotopia capabilities into Openhands with clear structure and professional formatting.

# Image Processing - Extract Figures from PDF

## Steps:
1. Use pdftoppm to convert specific PDF pages to images: `pdftoppm -f [start_page] -l [end_page] -png /workspace/survey.pdf /workspace/page[number]`
2. Use Python PIL library to crop figures from page images
3. Save cropped figures as PDF files
4. Verify figure quality and dimensions

## Example Commands:
- Convert page 3: `pdftoppm -f 3 -l 3 -png /workspace/survey.pdf /workspace/page3`
- Convert page 6: `pdftoppm -f 6 -l 6 -png /workspace/survey.pdf /workspace/page6`  
- Convert page 7: `pdftoppm -f 7 -l 7 -png /workspace/survey.pdf /workspace/page7`

## Python Code:
```python
from PIL import Image

def crop_and_save_figure(page_image_path, figure_id, crop_coords, output_path):
    img = Image.open(page_image_path)
    cropped = img.crop(crop_coords)  # (left, top, right, bottom)
    cropped.save(output_path, "PDF", resolution=100.0)
```

## Notes:
- Adjust crop coordinates based on visual inspection of page images
- Save as PDF for better quality and compatibility
- Verify all figures are created with appropriate file sizes
